metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Page One]
Washington
4th April 1848
My dear sir,
Understanding from your letter to
Mr. [Burt?], that is was desired to know my opinion,
whether it would be [advisable?] for the state to
be represented in the Baltimore convention,
I thought if most respectful to have a [meeting?]
of our delegation, to ascertain their views
before I undertook to ex[illegible] my opinion.
After full consideration they were of the
opinion, the state ought not to be [illegible]
and decidedly with the exception of Mr. [Sims?], who
[illegible] to differ, but declared he
would take no part.  It was, however, decided, 
that it would be [un?]advisable to make an
address to our Constituents, as it might look
like dictation. Each was left to write
and [confess?] his opinion.
It is well known that I have been [approved?]
to a convention to nominate a President
because it is [illegible] by the Constitution,
and is intended to supercede its [provisions?]
in reference to his election, as far as the [illegible]
is concerned. To that extent the [nomination?] is
in effect the election.  Because it destroys
the compromises of the Constitution between
the larger and smaller members of the Union,
as it relates to his election, be [securing?] to the former
this preponderance, in the electoral college, and de-
priving the [latter?] of this in the eventual election
by the House. Because, as constituted, the
convention is an [inaugural?] and [unfair?] repre-
sentation of the party. Instead of going to [each?]
state as representation in the Constitution,
in proportion to its relative party strength,
if [giving?] each the relative [weight?] it has
[Page Two]
in the electoral college, without the least
regard to its party strength.  The effect of
that is, to give several states in which
the democratick party has no weight, which
have not a vote in either House of Congress,
and which can command not a single
electoral vote, as much weight as others,
which give a unanimous vote in both 
houses, and an [illegible] electoral vote
the other way.  Now, as the non slave holding
states are much more populous that the 
slave holding, while they are far [left?]
democratical, it is apparent that the 
effect of the nominations is, to give a [illegible]
of the party, and  the least sound [illegible] of the
Union in a party [illegible], the control of the 
election.  The effect of that, again, is to sacri-
fice the interest of the slave holding state, and
to expose them, [illegible], to great danger,
if not certain [destruction?].
The first effect is to five a minority of the
party in the non slave holding states a control over the Executive Depart-
ment of the government, [illegible], who will be
elected, if he desires a [reelection?], of the election of a for-
[illegible] to succeed him, as he always
will, one or the other, he [must?], to accom-
plish his [object?] [illegible] the minority in those
states, as they have the control over the
nomination. To do that he most be-
stow his patronage freely on it, and accom-
modate his [meaures?] to their [illegible]
to the [illegible] and [illegible] of the interest of the
majority of the party  in the other states. But
still worse, he becomes for the time the
leader of the party, and, in order to sustain
[illegible] against the [illegible] of the opposition,
[Page Three]
the delegates from the states whose interest are thus
sacrificed are forced by party ties to defend him
in the very measures, by which they are.  Under
this influence, a minority of the party, in the
non slave holding states are [absorbing?] and [illegible]
a majority in the slave holding to their [own?]
on the most [illegible] of all questions to us; I 
allude to that, which relates to slavery.  It is
[owing?] to this cause, that we have not long
since united and put down abolition in the 
other states, as we might easily do, if united.
To long as it is permitted to operate, there is
[illegible] redemption for the slave holding states
then certain distinction if it is permitted to 
continue, will be the end. The process has
already commenced and made great progress, 
of which no stronger evidence can be furn-
ished than that they should consent to go
into the Convention prepared to be held
in May next in Baltimore.
Heretofore they would have met with indigna-
tion a proposal to meet in Convention [avowed?] and known
abolitionists.  A single individual of that des-
cription would have been sufficient to
[determine?] every delegate from the 
slave holding states from taking a [sect?] in
the Convention. But time, with the influences
of the cause stated, has already effected so great
a change, that all those states, with the excep-
tion of ours, have already, as is [believed?], ap-
pointed delegates to that Convention, although
it is well known, that is will consist of nu-
merous individuals, as hostile to our democra-
tick institutions, as Geddings, or any other abo-
litionists.  Indeed, there will be very few 
delegates from the non slave holding states, who
[Page Four]
will not on this all important question be
decidedly opposed to us.  Many of them, it is true,
will disavow the Wilmot proviso; but they will
support other measures being the same ob-
ject and not [illegible] fatal in there consequences
to us. To show how little reliance we can
place on the delegates from those states on this,
to [our?] [illegible] question, it is sufficient to state that
the legislature of N. [illegible] has just [illegible] our
act to make it [illegible] in any of its [illegible] to
aid, even the federal officers, in [delivering?] of
fugitive slaves to their masters.  It was with
the [exemption?] of two votes, [illegible] [illegible];
Whigs, B[illegible] and Hawkes all voting for it.
[Timber?] acts have been [illegible] by Michigan abd
other states, on the last [illegible] of their legislature
by the joint consent of all parties.
And yet, such is the progress which has already been
made to [illegible] [initiate?] our feelings with that of the non
slave holding states, on even this question,
that the entire slave holding states with, as
stated, the exception of ours, have agreed to go
into convention to be thus [compared?], to[illegible]
[illegible] by their joint action and [illegible]
for the Presidency. What is this, but, in effect, to
merge the abolition question, as far as the Presidency
is concerned? And what is that, but a declara-
tion, in effect, that abolition of slavery with
us, is a [illegible] evil-[illegible] to be dreaded than the de-
feat of the party in the presidential [illegible], which now decides the two par-
ties?
But it is said, that the [illegible] from the slave
Holding states go in with a fixed determination
not to agree to the [illegible] of any one,
who is not decidedly with us on the subject
of abolition.  Whether they can be bought
to take [firmly?] such a stand, remains to be
[Page Five] 
seen.  It is to be found, they will not, that
the desire to avoid defeat in the election,
and to preserve the [ascending?] of the party will
make them yield to the majority of delegates
from the non slave holding states. But, be
that as it may, it will not avert the danger, 
which must result from agreeing to [illegible]
and fraternize with known abolitionists. When
it comes to be fully established, that the aboli-
tion question is not to enter into the Presidential
[illegible], and that Southern planters may frater-
nize with abolitionists in nominating and [illegible]
Presidents, there will be little difficulty to the
election of an abolitionist. The first step
in all such cares, is the most difficult.  The
powerful cause, which has reconciled then
to unite in convention, with abolitionists to make
a president, is sufficient, if permitted to
continue to operate, to reconcile them to the 
election of an abolitionist.
Their thinking, I trust, our state will never
agree to take so debasing and fatal a step. It
may be, if she should resist the bad example,
that other states will follow her example
hereafter, and that this, otherwise fatal
step, may be prevented from becoming a
precedent.
I might add many other and [wrought?] reasons, just
going in at this time, and [many?] others the disorganiza-
tion of the party and the danger of being committed 
to the supporting a candidate, in whom we
ought not, and cannot confide.  And, also, that
we would have a far greater control by stand-
ing aloof, ready to throw our weight, where
it can be done with the most effect, 
to promote our principles and policy, than
[Page Six]
we probably could by going into the convention;
but I do not think it can be [illegible], after
the weighty objections, which have been stated.
Indeed, after having refused to connect herself
with [illegible] for so long a period, should
go into one [illegible], when the objectives are so
much [stronger?] than ever were before.
I must ask the [illegible] of you, to consider
this addressed to all our friends, who take an 
interest in the subject, as well as to [yours truly?]. I
hope, if you and they concur in the views, that our
paper will take such [illegible], as will be [calculated?]
to discourage any movement in favor of
a convention, if, indeed, there should
seem to be any danger of any of the kind.
Yours truly
J.[John] C.[Caldwell] Calhoun
H.[Henry] W.[Workman] Conner Sr.
